talk.start.para: y asked the Treasurer, upon notice -

item.para: Does the Government impose any restrictions on the expenditure of money provided by the Commonwealth to local government authorities under the federal rural road aid grant scheme?

While there still exists in a local government area a need for rural roads which are as yet unmade, but are required by primary producers, does the Government approve that finance made available under the scheme should be used to provide suburban roads in built-up areas or to construct scenic roads for tourist purposes?

talk.start.para: - The answers to the honorable member's questions are as follows -

item.para: The Commonwealth does not make road grants direct to local government authorities. Road grants are, however, made to the States under the authority of the Commonwealth Aid Roads Act 1959. That Act requires each State to spend not less than 40 per cent. of the total moneys received in each year on rural roads, " other than highways, trunk roads and main roads ". This proportion of the moneys provided by the Commonwealth must be expended - " (a) on the construction, reconstruction maintenance and repair of rural roads or on the purchase of road-making plant for use in connection with rural roads; or

item.label: (b)
item.para: in making payments to municipal and other local authorities for the construction, reconstruction, maintenance and repair of rural roads or for the purchase of road-making plant for use in connection with rural roads".

answer.para: A similar provision is included in the Commonwealth Aid Roads Act 1964.

item.para: The Government considers that, in keeping with existing constitutional arrangements relating to roads, the State Governments and their local authorities should be free to determine the specific projects upon which Commonwealth Aid Roads moneys, including those amounts reserved for rural roads, are to be spent. This view is understood to be shared by the State Governments and local government authorities themselves.

talk.start.para: d asked the Minister repre senting the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: Is it a fact that where a married pensioner couple are both entitled to pensioner medical service the normal practice is to issue only one medical entitlement card to serve both pensioners?

If so, can this often cause considerable inconvenience to the pensioners, not only in regard to medical and pharmaceutical services, but also in regard to travel on State transport where a medical card is usually accepted as proof that the person is a pensioner?
If this is the case, will the Minister take whatever action is necessary to ensure that medical cards are made available to both pensioners?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following replies -

item.para: Generally, a single entitlement card is issued to a married pensioner couple to cover their medical needs except in the case of a couple living apart.

In the majority of cases, it is considered that this does not impose any inconvenience upon pensioner couples so far as the Pensioner Medical Service or the Pharmaceutical Benefits Scheme is concerned. The question of travel on State transport is a matter for the State authorities, and it was never intended by the Commonwealth that the Pensioner Medical Service Entitlement Card should be adopted by such authorities for the purpose of identification.

Where special circumstances exist which render it desirable for a pensioner couple to have separate entitlement cards, a separate card is issued on receipt of an application setting out the reasons for the request.

talk.start.para: b asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice -

quote.para: Will the Minister consider the introduction of uniform legislation to regularise the use of X-ray equipment in the Slates?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following reply -

quote.para: The control of the use of ionising radiation, including the use of X-ray equipment is the constitutional responsibility of the sovereign States. Each State has enacted legislation based on a model act and regulations recommended by the National Health and Medical Research Council in 1954 and 1957 respectively. This legislation differs in some details between States, however, and the desirability of having more uniform legislation throughout the Commonwealth to regularize the use of ionizing radiation is under consideration. A committee of the National Health and Medical Research Council is at present reviewing the model act and regulations with this aim in mind.

talk.start.para: b asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: Did the Minister state that some drugs in Australia were approximately three times dearer than in Britain, and that action was being taken to reduce their cost?
What has been the result of negotiations with the drug companies?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following replies -

item.para: In response to a previous question from the honorable member, I advised him that in some few cases drugs are in the order of three times as costly in Australia as in the United Kingdom, but that in many other cases the difference is smaller. On a number of occasions I have stated that action was being taken to bring the prices of drugs in Australia more into line with the prices ruling on world markets. This action is continuing.

During the year ended 30th June 1964, negotiations with drug companies resulted in price reductions estimated on the basis of current prescribing levels to yield savings of approximately £2,700,000 in a full year.

Complete parity between Australian and British drug prices is not practicable because factors such as smaller usage and higher freight costs must be taken into account. However, for quite a number of frequently prescribed drugs the price differences are now more reasonable than in the past, and in some cases (he Australian price is even lower than the British price.

talk.start.para: b asked the Minister representing the Minister for Health, upon notice -

item.para: ls it a fact phenacetin can be harmful?
Does the drug Disprin contain phenacetin?
Why was Disprin removed from the Pharmaceutical Benefits list?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Health has furnished the following replies -

item.para: The National Health and Medical Research Council some time ago referred to the Royal Australasian College of Physicians the question of the possible ill effects of phenacetin if taken in excess. The College's Therapeutic Advisory Committee examined the matter, and the results of the Committee's findings were reported to the National Health and Medical Research Council in May 1953. The outline of the Committee's report was released by me in the form of a press statement on 4th June 1963. Briefly, the Committee did not feel justified, on the evidence available, in recommending that phenacetin should be banned or that the sale of analgesics should be restricted. The Committee did, however, consider that anyone who wishes to take these preparations daily should be warned not to do so except after obtaining medical advice and sanction. I am informed by my departmental medical advisers that no additional scientific evidence relating to the possible harmful effects of the long-term use of phenacetin has since been forthcoming.
No.

Disprin, a brand of acetylsalicylic acid soluble tablets, has never been listed as a pharmaceutical benefit. However, on the advice of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Advisory Committee, tablets of the same chemical content made by the manufacturer of disprin and by other manufacturers are available as pharmaceutical benefits for the treatment of pensioners.
